newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada April housing starts fall 7.8 pct.
newsitem.headline: Canada April housing starts fall 7.8 pct.

text.p: Canadian housing starts fell by 7.8 percent in April to a seasonally adjusted annual rate (SAAR) of 145,700 units from 158,000 units in March, the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corp (CMHC) said on Thursday.
A Reuter survey of economists had forecast housing starts of 157,750 units.
Actual housing starts rose to 13,207 in April from 8,208 the month before (revised from 8,189). The SAAR is a monthly figure adjusted to remove normal seasonal variation and multiplied by 12.
CMHC provided the following SAAR data for urban centres:
It said the national housing start total was nonetheless 36.6 percent higher than the 106,700 a year ago.

"Though slightly lower, the April figure is still one of the best since 1994," CMHC senior economist Michel Laurence stated. "Mortgage rate increases in March and April were a factor in slowing activity, but rates dropped again on May 3."
The provincial estimates are for centers with more than 10,000 people. The other area estimates are for centers with less than 10,000.
